sentence: How lovely to finally write to you again.
word: Wat leuk om jou eindelijk weer eens te schrijven.

sentence: again (after a long time, implies a sense of reunion or resumption)
I haven't seen you in a long time.
word: Ik heb je lang niet gezien.

sentence: There is a football field next to my house.
word: Naast mijn huis is een voetbalveld.

sentence: I play football there every Saturday with a few friends.
word: Daar voetbal ik iedere zaterdag samen met nog een paar vrienden.

sentence: "a few": Understanding of "nog" as "also/still" and "een paar" as "a few" is fundamental to Dutch language; not explicitly outlined in 1 but consistent with language norms.
I made new friends at the football club.
word: Ik heb nieuwe vrienden gemaakt op de voetbalclub.

sentence: Their names are Aman and Jan.
Jan is eighteen years old and also lives in Amsterdam.
word: Jan is achttien jaar en woont ook in Amsterdam.
Aman is de oudere broer van Jan.

sentence: I like the Netherlands very much.(The Netherlands pleases me very much.)
The only downside is that it rains quite often.
word: Het enige nadeel is dat het nogal vaak regent.

sentence: quite/rather (adverb indicating a moderate to high degree)
People are indeed very nice and always helpful.
word: De mensen zijn wel erg aardig en altijd behulpzaam.
Het leren van de Nederlandse taal gaat goed.

sentence: The only thing I find difficult is the grammar.
word: Alleen de grammatica vind ik lastig.

sentence: Let me know what it's like there in Germany!
word: Laat mij weten hoe het daar is in Duitsland!
Ik ben benieuwd naar je reactie.

sentence: I would like to introduce you to my family.
word: Graag zou ik jullie voor willen stellen aan mijn familie.

sentence: "I would you" (informal, plural), more naturally translated to "I'd like to introduce you to"
They have been married for over ten years.
word: Zij zijn samen al meer dan tien jaar getrouwd.

sentence: He looks a lot like me.
Robert, on the other hand, does not, because he has green eyes.
word: Robert daarentegen niet, dat komt omdat hij groene ogen heeft.

sentence: Besides people, our family also consists of our dog Becky.
word: Naast mensen bestaat onze familie ook uit onze hond Becky.

sentence: Becky is very sweet and likes to play outside.
word: Becky is enorm lief en vindt het leuk om buiten te spelen.

sentence: "vindt het leuk + infinitive", it expresses that someone enjoys doing something.
His youngest daughter Marjan has her birthday today.
word: Zijn jongste dochter Marjan is vandaag jarig.

sentence: There are four balls for sale in the store.
word: In de winkel zijn vier ballen te koop.

sentence: He pays the money at the store's cash register.
word: Hij betaalt het geld bij de kassa van de winkel.

sentence: The ball goes into his bag and Wim cycles home.
word: De bal gaat in zijn tas en Wim gaat op de fiets naar huis.

sentence: There are eight candles on the cake.
word: Op de taart staan acht kaarsjes.

sentence: Marjan is happy because it's her birthday.
word: Marjan is blij omdat ze jarig is.

sentence: Her grandmother and her uncle came to visit.
word: Haar oma en haar oom zijn op bezoek gekomen.

sentence: Marjan received a book and markers.
word: Marjan heeft een boek en stiften gekregen.

sentence: Then Wim gives the ball to Marjan.
word: Daarna geeft Wim de bal aan Marjan.

sentence: She thinks the ball is a nice present. Nice blue!
word: Ze vindt de bal een mooi cadeau. Mooi blauw!

sentence: despite the fact that he is small.
The only downside to my house is that there are a lot of mosquitoes in the summer.
word: Het enige nadeel aan mijn huis is dat er veel muggen zijn in de zomer.

sentence: Furthermore, I wouldn't want to live anywhere else.
word: Verder zou ik nergens anders willen wonen.

sentence: When I'm old, I want to continue living in Amsterdam.
word: Als ik oud ben, wil ik in Amsterdam blijven wonen.

sentence: Preferably in a house like this.
word: Het liefst in een huis als deze.

sentence: I often play football with them.
You probably don't have to worry.
word: Je hoeft waarschijnlijk niet bezorgd te zijn.

sentence: For example, we can go to the beach.
word: We kunnen bijvoorbeeld naar het strand gaan.

sentence:
Vertel comes from the verb "vertellen," which means "to tell" or "to narrate."
Eens in this context acts somewhat like an adverb meaning "once" or "for once," but it's used here to soften the command, making it more like an invitation or a casual prompt, similar to "go on" or "please."

"Meelopen" is a compound verb meaning "to walk along" or "to accompany".  Separable verbs split in certain grammatical constructions, with the prefix (in this case "mee") moving to the end of the sentence.  Ik loop wel even met u mee. 
Separate: "I walk just for a moment with you along"
Smooth English: "I'll walk along with you for a moment"
Here, "lopend" is not part of the verb conjugation but acts as an adverbial participle describing the manner of the action. It answers the question "how?" (How did you go? By walking.)
word: Van het station ben ik lopend naar school gegaan

sentence: "Can I go everywhere?", "everywhere" , "to" (indicating direction, as in movement towards something)
word: kan ik overal naartoe, overal, naartoe

sentence: "Hoef" (from "hoeven") means "need not" and fits the context of no obligation to wait, while "heb" (from "hebben") means "have" and is used for possession or different grammatical constructions.

The sentence as a whole indicates that the class or lesson started 15 minutes ago and is still ongoing. /// 
bezig - This means "busy" or "engaged in". When used after "is" like this, it implies that the action or event (in this case, the class) is currently happening.
word: De les is al een kwartier bezig.

sentence: "increasingly" or "gradually" (an adverb indicating progression or change over time)
"from time to time" or "occasionally" (an adverbial phrase indicating irregularity or sporadic occurrence)
Literally means "an hour or six," but idiomatically it means "around six o'clock." The word "of" here implies an approximation rather than an exact time.
"behalve" adds exceptions or alternatives, while "trouwens" introduces extra information or commentary.

A colloquial particle often used in spoken Dutch to soften or make the statement more friendly or reassuring. It doesn't have a direct English translation but can be thought of as similar to "you know" or "really" in certain contexts.

Literally translates to "out of my head," but it is an idiomatic expression in Dutch that means "by heart" or "from memory."  /// It implies that the speaker knows something without needing to look it up or check.
in spoken Dutch, the mixed form (links- of rechtsaf) is very common and perfectly acceptable.
word: Moeten we hier links- of rechtsaf?

sentence: Disbelief: "You can't be serious!"/// Surprise: "You must be joking!" ///Shock: "I can't believe it!"

Één: Emphasized form meaning "one."///
Een: Indefinite article meaning "a/an."///
Example:
Ik heb één kat. ("I have one cat.")///
Ik heb een kat. ("I have a cat.")
"vallen" is used idiomatically with "mee" to form the expression "vallen mee," which means "to turn out better than expected" or "to be less bad than anticipated."
like tidying up and washing dishes
in order to keep everything clean
The one who gets home first!
word: Degene die het eerst thuis is!
Wat is er aan de hand?

sentence: To come by, to drop by///Specifically for visiting or passing by///
to arrange, to handle, or to manage something.
to pay with a debit card
you pay the amount by card
The bank then sets the requirement that you earn enough.
word: De bank stelt dan wel de eis dat je genoeg verdient.

sentence: This is the first person plural past tense of the verb "doen" (to do). It means "we did".
This is the plural form of "spelletje", which means "game" or "little game".
As a result// Therefore// Consequently// Because of that //Thus

The use of 's in 's avonds laat (Dutch for "late in the evening") is a contraction of the old Dutch word des, which was a possessive form meaning "of the." While this form is no longer used in modern Dutch,
The plural past tense of the verb "zijn" (to be) in Dutch. It translates to "were" in English.
This is the third person singular present tense of the verb "draaien," which means "to turn" or "to run" (in the context of movies or shows). Here, it means "is showing" or "is playing."
This means "to pay a visit" or "to make a visit." Here, "bezoek" is a noun meaning "visit," and "brengen" is the verb "to bring" or in this context, "to make" or "to pay."
Short for "zijn," which can mean "his" but in this context, it's used in the phrase "met z'n" to indicate "with (a number of) people."
The ordinal number "tien" (ten) in a plural form used here to mean "ten" in the context of counting people. In this construction, "tienen" reflects the number of people in the group.///ئونىمىز
Together, this phrase means "to agree on" or "to arrange."
an attempt or effort to do something,

translates to something like "I'll hear (about it)" or "I'll find out (later)." It's a casual way of saying that the speaker is open and willing to be informed about the decision or choice when it's made. This phrase often implies that the speaker isn't in a rush for the information but expects to get it in due time.
very very expensive, really extremely expensive.
right in the center of the city center
Later we'll divide the total amount by ten. Okay?
word: Straks delen we het totale bedrag door tien. Oké?

sentence: Literally translates to "hangs of it" but idiomatically means "depends on it"
A combination of "er" (there, used here to form a pronominal adverb) and "van" (of). "Ervan" roughly translates to "on it" or "on that" in this context

Achternaam translates to surname or last name in English. It's the family name that you inherit from your parents, typically shared among family members./// Voornaam translates to first name or given name in English. This is the personal name given to an individual at birth or during a naming ceremony, which distinguishes them from others within the family.
the infinitive form of the verb used in the phrase "hangt ervan af."
de afgelopen means "the past" or "the last."
"Has quite grown" or "has significantly increased"///nogal is an adverb meaning "quite" or "rather,"///gegroeid is the past participle of "groeien," which means "to grow."
"gaat" and "door" are used separately but together convey the meaning of "continues."
"continues now still" or "is still going on now"
This is a combination of "daar" (there) and "van" (of), meaning "of that" or "thereof."
Once again, I agree with that.
word: Nog eens, daar ben ik het mee eens.

sentence:
"everywhere" or "all around."/// 
Uses "overal" to emphasize the ubiquity of the proximity.
I am sitting there on it./// The phrase "daar ... op" in Dutch can be used in various contexts to indicate a location or position.
Rivers run everywhere, you see ships everywhere.
word: Overal lopen rivieren, overal zie je schepen.

sentence: Again, Once more, Still, One more time
is the verb "to be" in the present tense, in the passive voice (i.e., "is being")
is the verb "to build" in the present participle form,
This is the plural present tense of the verb "groeien", which means "to grow".
This is the plural form of "woning", meaning "houses" or "dwellings".
This is the plural form of "bedrijf", meaning "companies" or "businesses".
"to drive" or "to ride" in the past tense
"points out to you" or "warns you about"
"Doesn't a friend do something like that?!" or "A friend wouldn't do something like that, would they?!"
word: Zoiets doet een vriend toch niet?!

sentence: "to celebrate a party" or "to have a celebration"
word: Ik ga toch naar de bioscoop.

sentence: It's raining, but I'm going outside anyway.
word: Het regent, maar ik ga toch naar buiten.

sentence: "Far from" or "Not by a long shot"
